newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada to ink C$4.5 billion atomic deal with China.
newsitem.headline: Canada to ink C$4.5 billion atomic deal with China.

text.p: Canada will complete a multibillion dollar deal this month to build two nuclear power plants in China, government officials said on Thursday.
The final pact will be signed during a visit to Shanghai by Prime Minister Jean Chretien.

The officials told reporters that China had agreed to safeguards, to be enforced by monitoring from the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency, under which it will not use any of the nuclear material for military purposes.
"They don't need us to proliferate. They have nuclear weapons already," one official said.
He added that France and Britain already had built reactors in China, and he said Canada's safeguards were stricter.

The deal is worth $4.5 billion Canadian ($3.4 billion U.S.) and will provide two heavy water reactors, each with a capacity of 700 megawatts, an official with the government's Atomic Energy of Canada Limited said.
He said such a reactor in the West could provide power to a city of 700,000 people, probably significantly more in China since its people use less energy.
Chretien plans to swing through Shanghai on Nov. 26 during a visit to Asia.
An agreement in principle for the reactors was signed during a trade mission to China in 1994.
After attending the Nov. 23-25 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Manila, Chretien is to fly to Shanghai and then visit Japan from Nov. 26-30.
